item.title: Covid: Trust regulator on AstraZeneca vaccine safety, Boris Johnson says
item.description: Inquiries into whether there is a link between the jab and rare blood clots are ongoing.

item.title: Richard Okorogheye: Police find body in search for missing student
item.description: Richard Okorogheye was last seen by his family on 22 March, when he left their home in west London.

item.title: Paris hits back at filthy streets hashtag campaign
item.description: Thousands of Parisians post pictures of rubbish, but city officials blame a "smear campaign".

item.title: Paul Ritter: Friday Night Dinner star dies at 54
item.description: Tributes are paid to the actor, who played dad Martin Goodman in the hit Channel 4 comedy.

item.title: Chris Sutton: 'I believe heading a football killed my dad'
item.description: Chris Sutton has opened up about the struggle of watching his dad, footballer Mike Sutton, suffer with dementia.

item.title: Test travel regime must be easy and cheap, says PM
item.description: It comes after airlines criticised plans to make travellers pay for pre and post-travel testing.

item.title: Covid passports: Certification is 'one option', vaccines minister says
item.description: Introducing Covid status certificates risks creating a "two-tier Britain", critics say.

item.title: IMF forecasts stronger recovery for world economy
item.description: The IMF has upgraded both its UK and global forecasts compared with what it projected in January.

item.title: Man in court after two-week-old baby killed in Brownhills crash
item.description: Two-week-old Ciaran Morris died after a car hit his pram in the West Midlands on Sunday.

item.title: PSNI say 41 officers injured during NI rioting
item.description: Ten arrests have been made in recent days, with further violence in Carrickfergus and Londonderry on Monday.

item.title: E3 2021: Biggest conference in gaming is going online
item.description: The video game conference was cancelled last year because of coronavirus.

item.title: Warwick team triumph in University Challenge final
item.description: Warwick University defeated opponents from Cambridge's Magdalene College in the BBC Two quiz show.

item.title: Watch the moment 'Mrs Sri Lanka' crown was stolen
item.description: Pushpika De Silva won the "Mrs Sri Lanka" pageant title, but the crown was taken in an on-stage altercation.

item.title: FND: ‘The most common condition you’ve never heard of’
item.description: Cassie, 18, suffers seizures and memory loss because of the neurological complaint FND.

item.title: White Cliffs sites considered for Dame Vera Lynn statue
item.description: Forces' Sweetheart Dame Vera Lynn immortalised the White Cliffs in one of her most famous songs.

item.title: Hunter Biden on addiction: My life is not a tabloid
item.description: The US president's son talks to the BBC about addiction, grief and his scrutinised work in Ukraine.

item.title: Capt Sir Tom 100: Family unveils NHS fundraiser's 'birthday challenge'
item.description: People are encouraged to raise money on what would have been the late NHS fundraiser's birthday.

item.title: Lil Nas X shares defiant message as he tops US chart
item.description: The rapper celebrates that he's "still here" after escaping from "the lowest point in my life".

item.title: Latest Trends: A1 x J1 on how Houseparty changed their lives
item.description: Fame, number two in the charts and a remix with Aitch. It's been a life-changing year for A1 x J1.

item.title: Light pollution: How lockdown has darkened our skies
item.description: One impact of lockdown is that there has been a big reduction in light pollution in some areas.

item.title: 'I make Van Goghs out of Fuzzy Felt'
item.description: Lucy Morrow, from Nottinghamshire, got creative after having to spend time off work due to surgery.

item.title: Terezin: The former WW2 ghetto falling into ruin
item.description: There are concerns that historical evidence will be lost if Terezin's buildings are not maintained.

item.title: The sailor living alone on an abandoned cargo ship
item.description: Seafarer Mohammed Aisha has been living on an abandoned cargo ship for four years, part of that time completely on his own.

item.title: Greenland election: Melting ice and mining project on the agenda
item.description: Just 56,000 people will vote but the US, China and others have a stake in the result.

item.title: Tool checks phone numbers from Facebook data breach
item.description: A new online tool lets users check their phone numbers against the leaked database.

item.title: Five animals to spot in a post-Covid financial jungle
item.description: As the world prepares for an economic reset, several creatures have emerged to help you navigate your way.

item.title: Khraniteli: The Soviet take on Lord of the Rings
item.description: A rediscovered Soviet TV version of The Lord of the Rings is drawing fans for all the wrong reasons.

item.title: Fibromyalgia and pain: 'How cooking gave me my family back'
item.description: Ian loved cooking, but after being diagnosed with fibromyalgia he had to think of new way to get into the kitchen.

item.title: Remote working: Is Big Tech going off work from home?
item.description: After much hype about working from home, some tech companies are getting cold feet.

item.title: 'We went here, there and everywhere to make it happen'
item.description: Budding academic entrepreneurs say that scientific discovery is only the start of the journey.

item.title: Coronavirus doctor's diary: How the virus has changed our sleep patterns
item.description: Coronavirus is clearly a virus that affects our nervous system - and it appears to have an impact on the brain's sleep patterns.

item.title: Vitamin D: The truth about an alleged Covid ‘cover-up’
item.description: The vitamin is being studied - but why do some claim evidence is being ignored?

item.title: 'Things got heated' - Chelsea boss Tuchel on Kepa-Rudiger row
item.description: Chelsea manager Thomas Tuchel says "things got heated" in a "serious situation" between Kepa Arrizabalaga and Antonio Rudiger on Sunday.

item.title: Birmingham boss Ward mediating between players and club after squad sends letter of complaint
item.description: Birmingham City manager Carla Ward is acting as conduit between club and players after the squad sent a letter complaining about conditions.

item.title: Westwood eyes 'special' Nicklaus record at Masters
item.description: Lee Westwood says it would be a "very special" moment to break Jack Nicklaus' record as the oldest player to win the Masters.

item.title: Manchester City post £126m loss for disrupted 2019-20 season
item.description: Premier League leaders Manchester City report a loss of £126m for the 2019-20 season which was disrupted by the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: 'I forgot to tell my parents I was England captain'
item.description: England centre Emily Scarratt says having a final in this year's reformatted Women's Six Nations could help the side's World Cup preparations.

item.title: La Liga highlights: Ousmane Dembele scores late winner for Barcelona
item.description: Watch highlights as Ousmane Dembele scores a 90th-minute winner for Barcelona while opponents Real Valladolid receive a controversial red card.

item.title: MLB: Early catch of the year candidate? Tampa Bay Rays' Randy Arozarena makes epic diving catch
item.description: Randy Arozarena of the Tampa Bay Rays makes a terrific diving catch, as the Boston Red Sox score only one run on the play.

item.title: What are the UK plans for Covid passports?
item.description: The government is considering how people could prove they are unlikely to transmit Covid.

item.title: What's the roadmap for lifting lockdown?
item.description: The rules on how many people can meet outdoors are changing, as lockdown is eased.

item.title: Covid: When can I go on holiday abroad or in the UK?
item.description: Anyone in England who travels abroad without good reason will soon face a £5000 fine.

item.title: How many cases are there in your area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Covid: When will I get the vaccine?
item.description: People aged 50 and over are urged to book their Covid vaccine in the next few days.

item.title: Covid: What is the rule of six and what are the social distancing rules?
item.description: Lockdown rules are being eased further in England and Wales so more people can meet up outside.

item.title: Covid: Can my boss force me to go to work?
item.description: As lockdown restrictions ease ease gradually across the UK, what are the rules about going to work?

item.title: Covid vaccines: How fast is progress around the world?
item.description: Charts and maps tracking the progress of Covid vaccination programmes.

item.title: Coronavirus: When will pools, gyms and hairdressers open?
item.description: Lockdown has been eased further - but what does it mean for hairdressers, pubs and gyms?

item.title: Covid vaccine: How many people in the UK have been vaccinated so far?
item.description: The logistics of vaccinating millions of people across the country, as more than 31 million people receive at least one dose.

item.title: Covid: When can pubs and restaurants reopen?
item.description: Hospitality venues are set to gradually open up in the spring as lockdown eases across the UK.

item.title: Lockdown rules: What are the restrictions in your area?
item.description: Use our search tool to find out about coronavirus rules and restrictions where you live.

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the rules for places of worship?
item.description: Places of worship are open across much of the UK, despite lockdown.

item.title: Coronavirus: Your tributes to those who have died
item.description: A collection of your tributes to some of the thousands of people in the UK who have died with coronavirus.

item.title: Why is the EU unhappy with AstraZeneca?
item.description: The EU has called on AstraZeneca to "catch up" on its deliveries to the EU.

item.title: What are the rules for weddings and when can I hold a reception?
item.description: Wedding ceremonies are still restricted across the UK, but the rules are easing.

item.title: Covid: What’s the problem with the EU vaccine rollout?
item.description: The coronavirus vaccine is being rolled out across the EU but there have been delays.

item.title: Covid: How are European countries tackling the pandemic?
item.description: Are European countries relaxing restrictions put in place to control a new wave of infections?

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the rules for face masks or face coverings?
item.description: As the UK cautiously unlocks, experts will review the evidence on when and where masks are needed.

item.title: Covid: What's happened to crime during the pandemic?
item.description: From dog theft to drug crime, lockdown has led to some big changes in policing.

item.title: What are the rules on dating now? And other questions
item.description: We answer some of your questions about England's roadmap out of lockdown, and other Covid-related issues.

item.title: Unemployment rate: How many people are out of work?
item.description: The unemployment rate is rising as Covid hits different parts of the economy.

item.title: Covid: The inside story of the government's battle against the virus
item.description: Twenty of Downing Street's most senior politicians, officials and former officials take you "into the room" where essential Covid decisions were being made.

item.title: Covid: The countries that nailed it, and what we can learn from them
item.description: A year into the pandemic, we look at countries that have had some success in tackling the virus.

item.title: Covid: What is the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine?
item.description: The Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccines should save many lives, say experts.

item.title: Race report: Was controversy part of the plan?
item.description: How the government handled the release of a contentious report on racial disparity in the UK.

item.title: 'We found a baby on the subway - now he's our son'
item.description: Danny Stewart saw something on the floor of an NY subway station - soon he would treasure it more than anything.

item.title: Letterbox contact: ‘Don’t my birth children have a right to know I’m dying?'
item.description: Diagnosed with a terminal illness, Hanna wanted to tell the twins taken from her at 16 - but had no way of reaching them.

item.title: The cost of speaking up against China
item.description: Uyghurs abroad describe a pattern of harassment and intimidation they say is designed to silence them.

item.title: The vaccine misinformation battle raging in France
item.description: Online conspiracy theories are exacerbating existing vaccine scepticism.
